title: Um dauða Skalla-Gríms og hversu hann var heygður

note: Manuscript Diversity, Meaning, and Variance in Juan Manuel’s El conde Lucanor (2006); and The Letter and the Cosmos: How the Alphabet Has Shaped the Western View of the World (forthcoming).
title: Laurence de Looze is a Professor of Comparative Literature at the University of Western Ontario. He publishes on a wide range of medieval and more modern literatures in English, Icelandic, French, and Spanish. His books include: Pseudo-Autobiography in the Fourteenth Century

container-title: Her books include Ethics and Action in Thirteenth-century Iceland (1998) and Tools of Literacy: The Role of Skaldic Verse in Icelandic Textual Culture of the 12th and 13th Centuries (2000). She is one of the editors of Skaldic Poetry of the Scandinavian Middle Ages
title: Guðrún Nordal is the director of the Árni Magnússon Institute for Icelandic Studies and a professor in the Department of Icelandic and Comparative Cultural Studies at the University of Iceland

container-title: Recent books include Danish Folktales, Legends, and Other Stories (2013), Interpreting Legend (2015), and the edited collections Nordic Mythologies
title: Tangherlini is a professor in the Scandinavian Section at UCLA. His work currently focuses on developing computational methods for addressing problems in the study of folklore and Old Norse‒Icelandic literature

container-title: His books include The Matter of the North: The Rise of Literary Fiction in 13th Century Iceland
title: and News from Other Worlds: Studies in Nordic Folklore, Mythology and Culture
Torfi H. Tulinius is a professor in the Department of Icelandic and Comparative Cultural Studies at the University of Iceland
The Enigma of Egill: The Saga, the Viking Poet, and Snorri Sturluson
